This is exactly why we need my #EvictionCrisisAct with @senrobportman to put in place steps to both prevent eviction and limit the harm when it is unavoidable. 

I'm honored our bill is supported by Desmond, one of the leading voices on addressing this crisis. pic.twitter.com/OQpMkLsZvj
And Desmond distills the hard truth of the crisis when he points out that, “eviction is not just a condition of poverty; it is a cause of poverty.”

The eviction crisis isn't just a big city problem, as Desmond points out. 

In Tulsa, for example, 1 in 13 renter homes is evicted each year.  

The eviction crisis affects urban, suburban, and rural communities across every region of the U.S.

Desmond continues, "As a result of these combined factors, the United States has transformed from a nation where eviction was once rare and drew crowds to a nation where losing your home has become commonplace."

If that doesn't describe a crisis, I don't know what does.

Third, inadequate federal funding for rental assistance to help families with rising housing costs. Families spend an average of 26 months on waiting lists for assistance. 

And as Desmond points out, "In our largest cities, the wait time isn't counted in years but decades."

Desmond points to 3 main factors as the cause of America's affordable housing crisis:

First, incomes for many families have been stagnant over the last several decades.

Second, as families watched their incomes flatline or even fall, their rents and utility costs were rising.

Compelling testimony from @just_shelter on America’s affordable housing and eviction crisis. As Matt Desmond says, this crisis isn’t just happening in big cities–it’s hurting families in suburban areas and rural communities in every region of the country. Thread on his remarks ⬇️
